The Buddha said:
Listen again to Devadatta's lack of gratitude in the past.
Long ago, there was a royal capital where the people were prosperous and the country was peaceful and prosperous.
The king had four sons:
The first was named Great Branch, the second was named Deputy Branch, the third was named Following Branch, and the fourth was named Small Branch.
As the four princes gradually grew up, they all married the daughters of neighboring kings as their wives. Together with their wives, they harbored thoughts of rebellion against their father.

When their father became aware of this, he banished them from the country. Each took his wife and left. As they traveled through the wilderness, their provisions ran out. Together they made a wicked rule: they should kill one wife, take her meat to fill their stomachs, and use it to sustain their lives so they could escape the long road.
At that time, Small Branch had this thought:
'It is better to die oneself than to take the life of another.
There is no other plan. We should secretly take my wife and flee to another country.'
Having thought this, he took his wife and fled.
Afflicted by hunger and thirst, his wife became exhausted and unable to proceed. She said to her husband:
'Holy son!
My life is coming to an end and I cannot continue on the road.'
Little Branch thought:
'I have kept her alive, this evil companion of a rÄká¹£asa. It would be deeply regrettable to let her die here.'
He then cut off the flesh from his thigh and gave it to her to eat, and he also pierced his arm to let her drink the blood.
His wife ate the flesh and drank the blood, and they slowly proceeded until they reached a mountain valley. They gathered roots and fruits to sustain their lives.

In the mountains there was a great river, and at that time there was a man who had been attacked by an enemy and his hands and feet had been cut off. He was thrown into the river and was crying out in pain, being carried away by the current.

Xiaozhi heard the cries of pain and, feeling compassion, went to investigate. He saw a man being carried downstream by the water. He entered the river, carried him on his back, and placed him on the riverbank.
Seeing that he had no hands or feet, he felt great pain and asked:
'Good man!
What happened to you that you suffered this misfortune?'
The man told him the story in detail.
Xiaozhi said:
'Even though you are suffering now, do not be afraid.'
He brought roots and fruits for him to eat and said to his wife:
'You should have compassion and take care of this person.'
Having received kindness and care, his wounds gradually healed. The wife felt love for him and often went to him to talk.
The bodhisattva, by nature, had little desire. Even when they gathered, he had no intention of engaging in sexual activity.

However, due to the Bodhisattva's spiritual power, all the roots and fruits in the mountain became extremely exquisite. The women ate them and it further increased their lustful thoughts. They went to the men and sought to engage in improper conduct.
The men refused, saying:
We almost lost our lives, but fortunately we were rescued by you. To do evil together would be to abandon your kindness. If your husbands find out, they will certainly cut off our heads.

The women repeatedly requested and were tormented by afflictions, so they eventually engaged in sexual relations and deeply became attached to each other, not wanting to be apart for a moment, and had no affection for their original husbands.
Although they sent them away, they did not follow. They then thought:
Now this woman is attached to me, and having an affair with another's wife is a great enemy. I will certainly suffer.
They then discussed together and told their wives:
If the husbands find out that we have engaged in improper conduct, they will certainly take our lives. There is no doubt about this.
When the women heard this, they agreed and thought of other plans.
The woman, who had knowledge without learning, immediately wrapped her head in cloth, put a stone under her head, and lay down.
When the younger brother returned with the fruit he had picked, he saw her unusual appearance and asked:
My dear!
What is the matter?
She replied:
Holy son!
My head hurts very much.
The younger brother said:
What can be done?
The woman secretly conceived a plan and with an evil mind told her husband:
Previously when I had a headache, the doctor had me apply bitumen to my head and it was cured.
The younger brother said:
Where can it be found?
I will go and look for it.
The woman said:
Under that cliff, by the mountain stream, I saw that medicine;
since it is so steep, I will look for it and come down, while you hold me from above.
He was a great man, of honest character and free from deceit, and he said:
So be it.
He tied a rope around his waist and hung over the cliff to pick the medicine, but his wife let go of the rope and fell off the cliff into the water.

Because that sentient being had a long life span and was destined to succeed to the throne, he did not die after falling off the cliff, but was carried by the water and drifted to the capital of the king.
The lord of that country had no son and died, so the ministers, officials, and citizens discussed together:
Since the king had no son and has now passed away, whom shall we establish to succeed to his position?
They called the physiognomists and asked them to find someone suitable to be king.
At that time, the physiognomists searched in all directions. There is a verse:
Even if one passes through a hundred kalpas, one's karma is not lost;
When the causes and conditions meet, one receives the retribution oneself.
At that time, Xiazhi, due to the ripening of his karma and being destined to receive the position of king, came out of the water and sat on the edge of the cliff.
However, because of the majestic virtue of the Bodhisattva, the place where he stayed had an extraordinary radiance.
At that time, the physiognomists happened to be traveling there. Seeing that this great man had the auspicious marks of a king, they were all delighted and went to inform the ministers, saying:
We have found a great man with the auspicious marks of a king, suitable to be the ruler of the country.
Upon hearing this, the ministers ordered the people of the country to decorate the city and prepare for the great ceremony. They selected an auspicious day to enthrone him as king.

However, there was still no queen of the country. The ministers announced to the noble families of various countries, saying that if there were any well-born and beautiful women, they should be well-adorned and brought to the capital. The one who pleased the king would be taken as the queen.
Because of women, the king had experienced great suffering, and he deeply felt revulsion and had no intention of looking at them.
The ministers said to him:
Great King, you should know!
If there is no queen, the royal lineage will be cut off. Beautiful women from all directions have gathered here, and we wish to enthrone one as the queen and as the king's concubines.
The king also did not agree, speaking of the faults of women.
Wherever beings with merit are, flowers, fruits, and food are all sweet and delicious, and they have much energy.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva fell off the cliff, in that mountain flowers, fruits, roots, and stems all ceased to grow. Even if they did grow, they were bitter and tasteless.
Because of the lack of energy in the roots and fruits, the two evil people gradually became weak and could not survive.
Then the evil woman carried the man without hands or feet on her back, left the mountain, entered the villages, and went around begging.
If others saw and asked:
Who is this?
She replied:
This is my husband.
Although he was like this in appearance, she had no other thoughts.
However, according to the country's laws, if a woman served her husband with chastity, many people respected her and made offerings.
This woman went to many places and obtained plenty of food and drink. In this way, she traveled and gradually reached the capital city.
When the people heard this, they all sighed in admiration, and some gave rise to joy and went outside to watch from afar.
When the people in the city saw this, they thought it was a skillful means and gave rise to criticism, saying:

The king says that women have many faults, but how can this be seen in this chaste woman, who carries her husband, who has no hands or feet, on her shoulders, goes from door to door begging for alms, and uses it to support him?
Then the gatekeeper saw the above events and reported them in detail to the king.
When the king heard these words, he ordered her to be summoned. The woman entered the inner palace. When the king saw her, he immediately smiled and spoke a verse, saying:
Eating thigh meat to fill hunger, drinking my blood to quench thirst;
Carrying a lump of meat on the shoulders, where is there chastity?
Evil plan to seek agarwood, hoping I will fall off the cliff and die;
Carrying a lump of meat on the shoulders, where is there chastity?
At that time, this woman heard the king's verse, and felt ashamed. She immediately lowered her head.
The ministers heard the verse but did not know its meaning, so they said:
'Great King!
What is the meaning of the verse you have spoken?'
The king then explained it in detail to the ministers.
The people in the city disliked this woman and together they called her evil and expelled her from the country.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
What do you think?
Is the one who was Xiao Zhi in the past someone else?
I am he.
The woman then is Devadatta now.
Not only does he have no gratitude now, but also in the past he was also like this.
You bhiká¹£us, listen further. Devadatta has no gratitude and repays kindness with enmity.

Long ago, there was a royal capital named Self-Mastery Friend. The people were prosperous, peaceful, and abundant. The king ruled with the right Dharma, respected the virtuous, benefited himself and others, always had great compassion, and constantly sought the wonderful Dharma. He deeply loved the people.

Later, when the queen gave birth to a son, his appearance was upright and extremely wonderful to behold. His complexion was radiant like a genuine gold ingot. His head had a parasol-like crest. His arms were slender and long. His forehead was broad and flat. His eyebrows were connected. His nose was high and straight. He was endowed with all the faculties.

His relatives gave him the name Self-Mastery. He was entrusted to eight wet nurses. As he gradually grew up, he was sent to school. He mastered everything, including mathematics, strategy, seals, secret scripts, and crafts. He was skilled in all the arts, such as riding elephants, horses, and chariots, archery, and wielding weapons.

Prince VijitÄvin was respectful, faithful, virtuous, kind, and generous. Benefiting himself and others was his fundamental practice. He always had compassion and universally loved the people. He abandoned stinginess and greed and practiced giving.

He had no stingy thoughts about any wealth or goods. The entire country knew and admired him. From far and near, from a hundred yojanas in the four directions, all the orphans and the poor came to gather, and he made sure they had no lack and all gave rise to joyful thoughts.

Once, the Bodhisattva rode in a carriage to a flower garden. The carriage was adorned with gold, silver, lapis lazuli, agate, and imperial blue gems. It was made of exquisite sandalwood for the shafts and yoke. On the carriage, it was adorned with the skins of lions, tigers, and leopards, with jeweled pendants. Those who saw it loved it. It was drawn by four horses, as fast as the wind, heading to the garden.
At that time, there was a wise and intelligent great brahman who came and said to the prince:
You should know that people in the world all hear of your practice of giving;
Although you cherish the jeweled chariot, you should give it to the brahmin.
At that time, when the Bodhisattva heard these words, he quickly got down from the chariot with a joyful mind, and pointed to the chariot, saying to the brahmin:
I now give up the jeweled chariot, joyfully giving it to the brahmin;
May I give up the three realms of existence and head for unsurpassed enlightenment.
At that time, the brahmin, having obtained the chariot and horse, rode away.

Another time, the Bodhisattva was riding a great white elephant named Increasing King, the color of which was as white as conch shell, snow, and silver flowers. Its seven limbs were perfectly round and complete with all characteristics, all well-established, just like Indra's Airavata. Its gait was leisurely and people enjoyed seeing it.
Surrounded by his relatives and attendants, it was like the full moon shining in the starry sky.

Moreover, it was the season of the three springs, with various flowers blooming, clear springs and pools, and harmonious singing of myriad birds. At that time, the Bodhisattva wished to go to the fragrant garden to temporarily enjoy the play.
At that time, an enemy from another country informed a Brahmin to beg the Bodhisattva for a great white elephant.
At that time, the Brahmin immediately raised his hand to the Bodhisattva and begged, also speaking a verse, saying:
All the human and heavenly beings, all have the same reputation for generosity;
The great white elephant you ride, you should give it to me to take away.
At that time, when the Bodhisattva heard these words, he immediately quickly dismounted from the elephant with a joyful mind, and pointed to the elephant, saying to the Brahmin:
I now give away the white elephant, joyfully giving it to the Brahmin;
I wish to leave the three realms of existence, and quickly head to the shore of enlightenment.
At that time, the ministers reported to the father king, saying:
'Prince VÄsavadatta has now given his great elephant to a brÄhmaá¹‡a who is an enemy of another country.'
When the king heard these words, he became very angry and ordered his attendants to summon Prince VÄsavadatta.
When he arrived, the king said to him:
'You should not stay in my country now.'
When the prince heard these words, he thought to himself:
'My father has abandoned me now. I am now seeking unsurpassed enlightenment and benefiting all. I will put on the armor of wisdom and give away this great elephant.
' He further thought:
'If I stay at home now, I will certainly not be able to give freely as I wish. I should go to the mountains and forests to uphold the precepts.
Therefore, I can now abandon my family affairs and live alone in the forest. To those who come to beg, I vow not to refuse.'
At that time, when the Bodhisattva had these thoughts, he returned to his palace and fully informed his wife.
When the queen heard this, fearing separation from her husband, she was filled with grief. She then joined her palms and said to the Bodhisattva:
Holy Son!
If it is so, I will also follow you to the mountains and forests. I cannot bear to part from you for even a moment. If we are separated, my life will not continue.
She then spoke a verse to the Bodhisattva, saying:ğŸ”½The sky without the moon has no radiance,
the earth without seedlings does not produce crops;ğŸ”½The lotus pond with dried up water,
a woman without a husband is also like this.
The Bodhisattva said:

The constant law of the world is that there must be separation. You were born and raised in the king's palace, with plenty of good food, clothing, bedding, and other necessities. Because of this pampering, your flesh is tender;
If in the mountains and forests, you would sleep on grass spread on the ground, eat fruits, and when picking flowers and fruits, walk through thorns.

Always upholding precepts and practices, I will also see the minds of the assembly as always firm. Those who come to make offerings, I will definitely give according to their wishes. When making the offering, do not give rise to sorrow.'
The Bodhisattva further said to the queen:
'You should be able to make good calculations yourself.'
The queen replied:
'I will follow the holy son's intention.'
The Bodhisattva further said:
'If it is so, always keep it in mind and make a vow.'
Having made the vow, the Bodhisattva went to the father king and said with a bow:
'Please forgive me, Father. I gave the great elephant to a Brahmin who is an enemy of another country.
Because of this mistake, I am going to the mountains and forests. May the king's treasury always be abundant and not lacking.'
Having heard these words, the king was sorrowful and grieved with sorrow and suffering, thinking of parting from his son. He then said to his son:
'You can stay here and do not go to the mountains and forests. Give as you wish.'
The Bodhisattva replied to his father, the king, in verse:
The great earth and all mountains and forests may be turned upside down,
But my mind of giving to beggars will never change.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken this verse, he took leave of his father and departed.
At that time, the prince's wife, children, and attendants, numbering in the thousands, all wept bitterly as they left the city together.
At that time, there was a person who heard the great crowd weeping and wailing, and asked:
Why are you all crying so sadly now?
They replied:
Have you not heard?
He then replied in verse:
In the city, there was a prince who gave away the precious elephant himself,
The king reprimanded him and banished him far away, which is why the crowd is weeping bitterly.
At that time, after the prince had left the city, he told his attendants:
'You may all return.'

You should now know that all kindness and love will eventually lead to separation, and that the gathering of relatives is not long-lasting, like travelers resting together under a tree, only to part ways after a short while.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½All the people in the world,
who gather together will eventually part.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had said these words, he traveled about thirty li and saw a Brahmin who came to the Bodhisattva and said:
Prince!
I have heard your fame spread far and wide, so I have come from thirty yojanas away, seeking a four-horse chariot. Please give me your four-horse chariot.
At that time, the prince's wife, having seen the Brahmin come to beg, gave rise to contempt in her heart and spoke to the Brahmin with coarse and evil words, then spoke a verse, saying:
How strange and evil you are, addressing the Brahmin, saying:
In the midst of the forest, he came to beg for the four-horse chariot.
At that time, the Bodhisattva said to his wife:
You should not speak ill of the brahmin.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
If there are no beggars, who will receive my offerings?
In order to attain enlightenment, I give everything away, eliminating stinginess.
The supreme merit of the six pÄramitÄs is called the practice of the bodhisattva;
In order to realize enlightenment, one fully cultivates omniscience.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken this verse, his mind was filled with joy. He further spoke a verse, saying:
I now remove the stain of stinginess and greed, and give the jeweled chariot to the brahmin;
The great sages of the past all practiced this way, and attained the place of uncontaminated enlightenment.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had made this vow, his mind was filled with joy. He held this jeweled chariot and gave it to the brahmin.
At that time, the Bodhisattva carried his son on his shoulder, and the queen also carried their daughter on her shoulder. They continued on their way and gradually reached the mountains and forests.
Having arrived at the forest, they gave rise to a little desire and then practiced precepts and abided there.
Later, at another time, there was a brahmin who came to the forest, went to where the Bodhisattva was, and sought the boy and girl.
At that time, Manthara had gone to pick fruit and was not there. The brahmin raised his hand in praise and said to the Bodhisattva:
Prince!
May you attain supreme victory.
He then spoke a verse to the Bodhisattva, saying:
I now have no attendants, and have sought everywhere with my wife;
I wish to be given these two children of yours.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having heard these words, was temporarily lost in thought, thinking of his beloved children. The brahmin then said to the Bodhisattva again:
Prince of the Kshatriya caste!
I have heard that you are able to give everything, so why should I hesitate in begging from you now?'
Then he immediately spoke a verse to the Bodhisattva, saying:ğŸ”½Your fame now spreads in all directions,
With compassion you give everything;ğŸ”½As I have heard before, you are able to give,
Now you should practice in accordance with that.
At that time, when the Bodhisattva heard these words, he then spoke a verse to the brÄhman, saying:ğŸ”½I will definitely give up my life,
My original vow does not give rise to a different mind;ğŸ”½Even if I were to give my children to others,
I would never turn back from this.
He further said to the brÄhman:ğŸ”½I now abandon the two children,
Husband and wife dwelling in the forest;ğŸ”½Women by nature are sorrowful and longing,
How can they remain alive?ğŸ”½Later people should not say of me,
That I am without compassion, abandoning my own children;
Unable to give up his own body, he offered his son instead.
At that time, the brÄhman said to the Bodhisattva:
Ká¹£atriya youth, you should not do this.

You were born and raised in the royal lineage. The people of this land all know and hear of you. Your fame extends to the ten directions, and you are in accord with all. You give rise to great compassion for all sentient beings. You give various things generously and make offerings with respect, just like a fragrant elephant.
You are able to accept and make offerings to all Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, teachers, the poor, and the orphaned and widowed. Whatever wishes they seek, you fulfill their original intentions.
Those who see you are drawn to you, and none pass by in vain. Whatever you encounter, you give generously. Your blessings are not wasted.

I have come from far away, enduring hardships to the utmost. I have something to beg for, hoping to fulfill my wishes. The mind is difficult to tame and cannot be fixed for long. It changes in an instant and cannot be made constant. Fearing that I may lose my original intention and be unable to give generously, I will return home exhausted and disappointed. You should now fulfill my original vow and let me go.'
He then praised the Bodhisattva in verse, saying:
Renowned in the ten directions, able to give to all;
I hope you will take pity on me and let me fulfill my hopes.
At that time, when the Bodhisattva heard these words, he felt sorrowful and distressed at the thought of parting from his beloved children. He then thought to himself:
If I now give away the two young children to this Brahmin, I and MÄdrÄ« will experience great sorrow and suffering due to parting from our beloved children.
If I do not give them away, it will greatly contradict my practice of austerity.

The brahmin, having lost his original hope, left empty-handed. I will now definitely experience the great suffering of separation from my beloved child. This place will burn me, but I cannot go against my original vow and violate my pure conduct.'
His mind then became determined to give up his son, and he made a vow, speaking a verse, saying:
I now give up this child, wishing to attain great beneficial results;
With this special merit, may I deliver sentient beings from the ocean of suffering.

At that time, as soon as the Bodhisattva gave away his son and daughter, the entire earth shook in six ways. The sages living on the nearby mountain, seeing the earth shake, were all startled and said to each other:ğŸ”½By whose power and what causes and conditions has this great earth suddenly shaken?
Now we should carefully observe whose power has caused this auspicious sign.
Among the sages, there was an elder sage who was well-versed in astrology and divination, and he spoke a verse to the other sages, saying:
This is the Bodhisattva who delights in the mountains and forests, subsisting on fruits and drinking water to sustain his life;
The beloved child has now been abandoned, and therefore the earth has this sign.
At that time, the two children, knowing that their father had given up on them, wept sorrowfully. They bowed at their father's feet and said with their palms joined,
May our father take pity on us and not abandon us. Now that we have no father, on whom can we rely?
At that time, when the Bodhisattva heard these words, his heart was filled with sorrow and his eyes filled with tears. He then spoke a verse to his beloved children, saying:
Children, you should know that I am not without love and compassion;ğŸ”½In order to save sentient beings from suffering, I am therefore abandoning my children's bodies.
With this supreme merit, I will deliver sentient beings from the ocean of suffering;
May they be able to escape from the path of delusion, and together attain the fruit of enlightenment.'

At that time, the two young boys, having heard their father's words, knew that their father was determined to give them away, and with tears of grief, they bowed their heads and joined their palms together. Choking with sobs, they spoke to their father in verse, saying:
Father, you are now determined to give us away, and we now entrust our last words to our mother;
If we have ever made any mistakes in the past, we pray that our mother will take pity on us and forgive us.
Because we are young and foolish, we have not followed and respected our parents' teachings;
Now we are unable to repay our parents' kindness, and we pray that you will forgive us for these faults.'
At that time, after the children had spoken the verses, they bowed their heads at their father's feet, circumambulated him three times to the right, and left with tears filling their eyes.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, thinking of the young boys' sorrowful words, was filled with sorrow and suffering. He gave rise to the mind of enlightenment and then entered the grass hut.
As soon as the two children left the grass hut, this trichiliocosm shook in six ways. Immeasurable hundreds of thousands of devas in the sky said like this:
Alas, what a wondrous event!
With different mouths but the same voice, they spoke a verse, saying:
The great majestic virtue of the rare offering, the bodhisattva's resolute mind;
The two young children born from his body, he abandons them all without regret.

At that time, the mother of the two children, Mandarava, having picked fruits and obtained them, was about to come to the grass hut. Seeing the great earth shaking in six ways, her mind was startled and she quickly went to the hut.

At that time, a deva transformed into a lioness and blocked the road, seeing that the Bodhisattva, wanting to deliver all sentient beings, was now abandoning his two children. Fearing that Mandarava would have difficulty in her mind regarding the perfection of giving,
When ManicÅ«á¸a saw the lion blocking the road, he spoke a verse in reply to the lioness, saying:
You are the wife of the lion, king of beasts, why do you block my road?
I now serve your husband together with you, you should quickly move away and let me pass.
You are the wife of the lion, king of beasts, I am the queen consort of the human king;
together we are united in righteousness as sisters, you should open the road and let me pass.
At that time, the magically created lion heard these words and moved out of the way.

At that time, ManicÅ«á¸a saw various evil omens on the road, namely, hearing cries of grief in the sky, and hearing the various beings dwelling in the mountains and forests all weeping and sighing. In a moment, he thought:
I see such omens, there must be something inauspicious in that grass hut.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
I now have double vision, and the birds are crying in sympathy;
Causing my heart to be deeply sorrowful, I will certainly be separated from my children.
Thus the great earth trembles, and body and mind both shake;
The whole body is now uneasy, and I certainly know it is a matter of separation.
At that time, after Manthara had sung this verse, thinking of a thousand kinds of harmful things, she went to the grass hut.
Having entered the hut, she looked everywhere but did not see the two children. Her heart was filled with sorrow and she thought like this:
'My two children are not playing with the little deer, and are they playing by making a city out of gathered earth?'
She immediately went to search for them, but having searched and not seen them, she thought again:
'Because they did not see me enter the hut and sleep.

Thinking this, with a fearful mind wanting to see her children, she abandoned the flowers and fruits she had gathered to one side. With tears filling her eyes, she bowed her head to the feet of her husband and asked:
'Where are my two young children now?'
At that time, the Bodhisattva replied in verse:
A brahman came here begging, surpassing others;
I gave him my two children. You should rejoice.

When Manthara heard these words, she was like a doe wounded by a poisoned arrow, fainting and rolling on the ground. She was like a fish on land writhing about. She was like a quail bird grieving for its lost young. She was also like a cow mother lowing in grief.
At that time, Manthara lamented in this way, speaking a verse:
My two children, their faces like flowers, their hands and feet soft like lotus leaves;
Together we will endure this suffering, how can I leave you alone?'

At that time, Indra, knowing that the Bodhisattva was together with Queen ManoharÄ making a difficult and determined vow, surrounded by the Thirty-three Celestials, descended from the sky, his radiance illuminating, to the hermitage in the forest where the Bodhisattva was staying.
In the sky, he spoke to the Bodhisattva in verse, with the following verses:
At that time, after Indra spoke these verses, he made the Bodhisattva's mind firm and courageous, and thought:
'Now the Bodhisattva only has Queen ManoharÄ as his attendant. If someone begs him to give her away with certainty, then there will be no one to serve the Bodhisattva.
I should now beg for Queen ManoharÄ and take her back.
' For the time being, he entrusted her to the Bodhisattva, and suddenly disappeared.
At that time, not long after, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, transformed himself into a brÄhman, went to where the Bodhisattva was, and spoke a verse, saying:
This wife's appearance is extremely beautiful, she is solely devoted to serving her husband;
Such a noble and beautiful wife, I hope you will give her to me to serve.
At that time, when Madam Mandeville heard these words, her heart was filled with sorrow and anger towards the beggar, and she said these words:
You are one who is shameless and greedy, the most evil person in the world;
If you know the Dharma and recognize noble appearance, how could you forcefully beg for me from your husband?
At that time, the Bodhisattva felt sad in his heart and looked back at his wife. His wife spoke a verse, saying:
My heart is not sorrowful now, nor do I worry about the suffering of my body;
I only worry that you will stay alone, how can you survive?
At that time, the Bodhisattva replied to the queen in verse, saying:
I am not worried about staying here, I seek the firm and indestructible path;
You just respectfully follow and leave, I will die in the forest like a wild animal.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva spoke this verse, his mind was filled with joy and he spoke another verse, saying:
This is the last offering I make on this mountain, after the queen leaves, I have no worries.
Having spoken half a verse, at that time the Bodhisattva took Manthara with one hand, held a water pot with the other hand, faced the brahmin and spoke a verse, saying:
This person is pure and unstained, his words are eloquent and skillful;
Now I offer my cherished wife, may you accept her and protect her.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had given away his wife, he made this vow:
'May the blessings of this offering quickly lead to becoming a Buddha.'
